head.title: The Court's Term Is Over, but Not the Discord; The Miranda Ruling

identified-content.classifier: Miranda V Arizona (US Supreme Court 1966 Decision)

hedline.hl1: The Court's Term Is Over, but Not the Discord; The Miranda Ruling

abstract.p: Michael Griffith letter points out that Chief Justice Rehnquist's ruling on Miranda was more concerned with reaffirming Supreme Court's power in matters constitutional than with upholding warnings to criminal suspects (S)

block.p: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist did not exactly affirm Miranda (front page, June 27); he declined to overrule it. The main thrust of his decision is the reaffirmation of the power of the Supreme Court in matters constitutional, and especially in any conflict with Congress. Ever since Marbury v. Madison in 1803, Congress has sought to rein in the court.

Madison in 1803, Congress has sought to rein in the court.
Chief Justice Rehnquist is protecting his institution's prerogatives. Ultimately, most arguments are essentially about power, and in settling such arguments all else is a secondary consideration.
